It's Election Day in the Philippines Monday.
Half of the Senate and all of the House of Representative seats are up for grabs.
And the outcome will be a test of President Rodrigo Duterte's grip on power.
NPR's Julie McCarthy profiles the only woman running for the Senate on the opposition's slate of candidates.
She's a Muslim lawyer and a women's rights advocate.
Wearing a white headscarf wrapped turban-like, Samira Gutoc is a live wire in this campaign.
(CROSSTALK)

She's at ease whether she's slurping noodles from a banana leaf with farmers or swaying to the music at a rally, which delights crowds in the Philippines' song-and-dance political culture, or mustering a spirited defense against President Duterte's maligning of opposition parties.
Election time, character assassination time.
Duterte accuses the opposition of plotting to oust him and claims politicians of all stripes are involved in illegal drugs.
Instead of hurling accusations, Gutoc asks, why don't you figure out issues like poverty?
She gently jabs Duterte for not confronting China over its aggression in the South China Sea, which has hurt Filipino fishermen and which Gutoc calls a sellout.
Riding along as she travels, Gutoc tells me...
If you are bowing to China, you should bow more to your fisher folk or farmers.
People who are prejudicing our future are in the other side.
The opposition senatorial slate careens between farmers beneath coconut trees, social service groups at a local cathedral and a serenaded lunch.
(Singing in foreign language).
Between stops, Gutoc ducks into her van to reapply lipstick and rearrange her headscarf.
She's a Muslim in a country that is 92% Christian, and her race is nationwide.
But Gutoc's religion does not appear to be an issue.
She generates more of a stir as the only woman among the male-dominated lineup of opposition senatorial candidates known as the Straight Eight, which is how they'd like voters to mark their ballots.
But rally after rally, Gutoc is the fiery fresh face who can break out into song about the loneliness of Filipinos who work overseas.
(SOUNDBITE OF RALLY)
(Singing in foreign language).
Gutoc has been tested, not in high office but in war.
Her hometown of Marawi on the restive southern island of Mindanao was laid waste in 2017 when Philippine government troops battled ISIS-linked militants who had dug into the city.
Gutoc led volunteers in rescuing residents trapped during the five-month-long siege and is displaced herself.
The experience animates her belief she can serve.
Because I can talk about their struggle.
And it's also the struggle of anyone, to try to find a house and shelter and safety.
Duterte jokingly exhorted soldiers to commit rape during the Marawi siege.
Gutoc called the remark offensive and quit a local peace panel to which Duterte had appointed her.
In the campaign, she sounds the alarm about rape in a country where data show a woman is sexually assaulted every 72 minutes.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We have got to band together, join together and file a claim against that bastard who did it to us.
Her call to report rape resonated with 21-year-old coed Michele Orbeta.
When she opened up about that during the forum, I could tell, especially amongst my fellow students, it really got everyone's attention.
(CROSSTALK)
Women of all ages literally embrace Gutoc and eagerly snap selfies with her.
Her biggest hurdle in Monday's election may be name recognition.
But beside each candidate's name is a number.
Gutoc is 36, which she's used to good effect.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking foreign language).
Thirty-six is my ballot number, the stout Samira Gutoc tells audiences, and my waistline.
Julie McCarthy, NPR News, Manila.

They all, at some point in their career got, something terribly wrong.

Take Darwin, for example.
His theory of evolution by natural selection, the key to that theory, the way favorable traits are passed on, it's through genes.

Ron, do you feel like that is a problem?
Not really.
Again, we're talking about some confusion here.
I don't think that's necessarily a problem.
And I think there's an attempt here really to rein in the voting base of the Democratic Party.
When you look at the new regulations the IRS has tried to send out to clarify this, one of the items there has to do with the timing of a communication that coincides with an electoral campaign.

And, Bishop, from your standpoint, what is the Interfaith Alliance doing to really try to clarify for both liberals and conservatives, or people who may not even want to classify themselves who are members of faith community, what can and can't be done?

What we did in the 2004 election, we're doing in this election cycle and we'll be doing again in 2008.
Putting out voter guides for houses of worship and another one for candidates, public persons running for public office.

And these help houses of worship, whether they be Muslim, Jewish, Christians, see - any house of worship - what they can do that is permissible within the First Amendment to try to help them clarify that so that they understand that.
We also do those guides for the candidates themselves as to what they can do.
It's really very important to us to maintain the separation of religion and government.
And our primary focus is on religious liberty so that people who are religious or not religious certainly go to the polls and vote.
